questions.text: A researcher is comparing two international indices: Human Development Index (HDI) and Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI). Which of the following statements are true regarding these indices? HDI includes income measurement while PQLI does not. PQLI considers gross national income (GNI) as a parameter. HDI uses geometric mean, whereas PQLI uses simple averaging. Both indices incorporate infant mortality rate directly.

Regarding the Multi-dimensional Poverty Index (MDPI), which of the following statements are incorrect? The MDPI uses 3 dimensions and 10 indicators to assess poverty. A household without access to improved drinking water but within a 20-minute round trip is considered deprived. MDPI considers a child not attending school up to class 8 as educational deprivation. MDPI is heavily dependent on per capita income for scoring.

A 35-year-old man dies due to a preventable road traffic accident. Health authorities decide to calculate the impact on public health statistics. Which of the following measures would most appropriately capture the premature mortality loss in this case?
Following are the characteristics of Sentinel Surveillance. All are correct except:

options.label: B
options.text: Aims to monitor general population routinely

options.label: D
options.text: Focuses on a specific clinical sub-population (e.g., STD clinics)

questions.correct_answer: B. Aims to monitor general population routinely
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Aims to monitor general population routinely

questions.text: Assertion (A): Disability can occur independently without any impairment if psychological adaptation is sufficient. Reason (R): Disability is always secondary to impairment and restricts normal activities.

options.label: A
options.text: Both A and R are true, and R explains A

options.label: B
options.text: Both A and R are true, but R does not explain A

options.label: C
options.text: A is true but R is false

options.label: D
options.text: A is false but R is true

questions.correct_answer: D. A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: Ans. D) A is false but R is true

questions.text: A hospital administrator is reviewing key metrics to evaluate healthcare utilization in a district hospital. Among the following measures, which one is not classified as a direct utilization rate?

A community health program is implementing strategies aimed at preventing various cancers. As part of the review, which of the following interventions would not be classified as a primary prevention measure?
A hospital infection control committee is updating its airborne isolation protocols. For which of the following diseases is airborne isolation specifically recommended to prevent transmission?

An epidemiologist is analyzing an outbreak linked to a contaminated water supply, where new cases continued to appear steadily over several weeks. Which of the following features is most likely characteristic of a continuous common source epidemic?

options.label: B
options.text: Duration more than one incubation period

options.label: C
options.text: Rapid rise and fall of epidemic curve

questions.correct_answer: B. Duration more than one incubation period
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Duration more than one incubation period

questions.text: In the classic iceberg analogy for disease burden, if the submerged portion grows disproportionately larger than the tip, which of the following public health strategies becomes critically important?

options.label: A
options.text: Exclusive treatment of clinically diagnosed patients

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the Evidence Pyramid are true? Meta-analyses are considered higher in clinical relevance than individual randomized controlled trials. Cohort studies rank higher than case-control studies because they better establish temporal relationships. Systematic reviews are considered unfiltered information sources. Ideas and editorials rank above case reports in the evidence hierarchy

In the region of Medora (population: 5,00,000 at mid-year), a new viral outbreak called "Virogen-X" occurs over one year. Data collected: Total deaths in Medora during the year: 3,500 Deaths specifically due to Virogen-X: 700 Total number of Virogen-X confirmed cases during the year: 4,000 Number of total new Virogen-X cases who survived: 3,300 Number of Virogen-X patients still alive at 5-year follow-up: 2,970 Which indicator gives the best estimate of the relative burden of Virogen-X deaths compared to all deaths?
Which of the following statements regarding standardization is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Direct standardization can be used even without age-specific death rates available.

options.label: B
options.text: Indirect standardization adjusts observed deaths using standard ASDRs.

options.label: C
options.text: Segi World Population cannot be used unless national data is available.

options.label: D
options.text: Standardized Mortality Ratio (SMR) is used in direct standardization.

questions.correct_answer: B. Indirect standardization adjusts observed deaths using standard ASDRs.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Indirect standardization adjusts observed deaths using standard ASDRs

questions.text: In a village of 5,000 people: 250 residents developed dengue fever during the monsoon. At the peak of the epidemic, 400 residents were simultaneously sick with dengue (old + new cases). What is the attack rate and point prevalence at the peak?
A study showed: RR = 2.5 for obesity and breast cancer AR = 60% PAR = 15% Which statement is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Obese women have 2.5 times the risk of breast cancer compared to non-obese.

options.label: B
options.text: 60% of breast cancer in obese women is attributable to obesity.

options.label: C
options.text: Eliminating obesity would prevent 60% of breast cancer cases in the entire population.

options.label: D
options.text: 15% of all new breast cancer cases in the population would reduce if obesity is eliminated.

questions.correct_answer: C. Eliminating obesity would prevent 60% of breast cancer cases in the entire population.
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Eliminating obesity would prevent 60% of breast cancer cases in the entire population

questions.text: Which of the following advantages are unique to nested case-control studies (compared to traditional case-control)? Stronger internal validity Prospective exposure data available Lower cost than full cohort analysis Better external generalizability
A researcher conducts a randomized controlled trial (RCT) for a new vaccine in a single elite hospital with young healthy volunteers. Which is most likely true?

options.label: A
options.text: High internal validity but poor external validity

options.label: B
options.text: High external validity but poor internal validity

options.label: C
options.text: High both internal and external validity

options.label: D
options.text: Low both internal and external validity

questions.correct_answer: A. High internal validity but poor external validity
questions.explanation: Ans. A) High internal validity but poor external validity

questions.text: Which is not a feature of a nested case-control study?

options.label: B
options.text: Exposure data collected after outcome develops

questions.correct_answer: B. Exposure data collected after outcome develops
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Exposure data collected after outcome develops

questions.text: A public health department reports that cities with higher rates of green space have lower rates of asthma admissions. Based on this finding, a physician concludes that every child living near parks will have lower asthma risk. This conclusion is most affected by which of the following?

In a study examining the relationship between alcohol consumption and liver cirrhosis, the association is found to be much stronger among patients with hepatitis B infection compared to those without it. Which epidemiological concept best explains this?

In a large study investigating the relationship between aspirin use and gastric cancer, stratification for smoking is attempted, but the strata are too small for analysis. Which method would better control for multiple confounders simultaneously in this case?

You are reviewing a meta-analysis evaluating aspirin use for primary prevention of cardiovascular disease. The authors note substantial variation among included studies regarding aspirin dosage, patient ages, and outcome definitions. Which limitation best describes this concern?

Which of the following statements are true regarding specificity in Hill’s criteria? It implies a single cause leads to a single effect. It is the strongest proof of causal association. It is difficult to establish because diseases often have multiple causes. Specificity is more critical for infectious diseases than for multifactorial diseases.
Which of the following statements about serial interval is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Serial interval is longer than generation time in most cases.

options.label: B
options.text: Serial interval provides an indirect measure of incubation period in primary cases.

options.label: C
options.text: Serial interval measures attack rate among susceptible contacts.

options.label: D
options.text: Serial interval applies only in non-communicable diseases.

questions.correct_answer: B. Serial interval provides an indirect measure of incubation period in primary cases.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Serial interval provides an indirect measure of incubation period in primary cases

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding contraindications to vaccination is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Typhoid vaccines are safe to administer during febrile illnesses.

options.label: B
options.text: Yellow fever vaccine is contraindicated in infants <6 months of age only.

options.label: C
options.text: Pneumococcal vaccine is contraindicated in children <1 year.

options.label: D
options.text: Pertussis vaccine is contraindicated in epilepsy controlled by medications.

questions.correct_answer: C. Pneumococcal vaccine is contraindicated in children <1 year.
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Pneumococcal vaccine is contraindicated in children <1 year.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman receives the seasonal influenza vaccine. She develops mild swelling and tenderness at the injection site. Which adjuvant, present in some influenza vaccines, is most likely responsible for this local inflammatory reaction?

Which of the following statements are true? Vaccine-associated paralytic poliomyelitis (VAPP) is most commonly associated with killed polio vaccine. Both Cholera vaccine and Yellow fever vaccine can be given together without contraindications.
Which of the following vaccines is not allowed to be reused even if expiry date, cold chain, VVM, and aseptic technique are maintained?
Which of the following vaccines cannot be administered at the 10-week immunization visit according to the NIS 2023–24?
A pilot project introduces the Mycobacterium indicus pranii (MIP) vaccine to high-risk individuals in Bihar. What is the key additional intervention necessary during MIP vaccine administration?

A new rapid test for influenza has a likelihood ratio for a positive test result (LR⁺) of 12 and likelihood ratio for a negative test result (LR⁻) of 0.08. Which of the following is the best conclusion about the performance of this test?

options.label: A
options.text: It is useful to confirm disease only

options.label: B
options.text: It is useful to rule out disease only

options.label: C
options.text: It is useful for both confirming and ruling out disease

options.label: D
options.text: It is poor for both confirming and ruling out disease

questions.correct_answer: C. It is useful for both confirming and ruling out disease
questions.explanation: Ans. C) It is useful for both confirming and ruling out disease

questions.text: Match the following tools with the appropriate analytical property: Which of the following sets correctly matches each tool to its primary purpose?
Which of the following best describes the purpose of the log-rank test when comparing two Kaplan-Meier survival curves?

options.label: A
options.text: Adjusts for confounding variables between groups

options.label: B
options.text: Tests the difference in median survival times

options.label: C
options.text: Compares the overall survival experience between groups

options.label: D
options.text: Measures the proportional hazards ratio directly

questions.correct_answer: C. Compares the overall survival experience between groups
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Compares the overall survival experience between groups

questions.text: A diagnostic test for pancreatic cancer has an area under the ROC curve (AUC) of 0.92. Which of the following most accurately describes this AUC value?

options.label: A
options.text: The test has poor diagnostic ability

options.label: B
options.text: The test is equivalent to random guessing

options.label: C
options.text: The test has excellent ability to distinguish disease vs no disease

options.label: D
options.text: The test sensitivity is equal to its specificity

questions.correct_answer: C. The test has excellent ability to distinguish disease vs no disease
questions.explanation: Ans. C) The test has excellent ability to distinguish disease vs no disease

questions.text: A public health department is choosing between four screening tools for community-based screening of a highly transmissible disease. Budget constraints allow use of only one. Based on the ROC curve, which test would most appropriately balance high sensitivity with minimal false positives for use in mass screening?
Which of the following is the best interpretation of the data presented in the Kaplan-Meier plot, as shown below?

options.label: A
options.text: Treatment A has a significantly longer median survival than Treatment B

options.label: B
options.text: Treatment B has a significantly longer median survival than Treatment A

options.label: C
options.text: There is no statistically significant difference between the treatments

options.label: D
options.text: The two treatments have equal survival probabilities at all time points

questions.correct_answer: B. Treatment B has a significantly longer median survival than Treatment A
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Treatment B has a significantly longer median survival than Treatment A

questions.text: A 5-year-old presents with paroxysms of cough and inspiratory whoop. A sibling had similar symptoms 2 weeks ago. You suspect pertussis. At what stage is the affected sibling most likely to still be contagious?

options.label: B
options.text: Until 3 weeks after paroxysmal stage begins

options.label: D
options.text: Pertussis is not contagious after catarrhal stage

questions.correct_answer: B. Until 3 weeks after paroxysmal stage begins
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Until 3 weeks after paroxysmal stage begins

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the period of communicability of infectious diseases is/are true? Meningococcal infection ceases to be communicable once nasal/throat secretions are absent. Rubella and Measles share the exact same communicable window relative to rash. Hepatitis B remains communicable as long as HBsAg is detectable. Tetanus is communicable in the early stage of wound infection.
Which of the following disease pairs have the longest difference in incubation period ranges?

A 3-month-old infant is brought to the clinic with a 3-day history of cough. The mother reports that the baby is feeding normally and has no history of fever. On examination, the respiratory rate is 58/min, there is no chest indrawing, and no danger signs are noted. A bronchodilator trial was given but did not significantly reduce the respiratory rate. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Reassure the mother and advise home care

options.label: B
options.text: Start oral amoxicillin and review after 3 days

options.label: C
options.text: Refer urgently to a tertiary hospital

options.label: D
options.text: Observe the child for 1 hour and repeat RR before decision

questions.correct_answer: B. Start oral amoxicillin and review after 3 days
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Start oral amoxicillin and review after 3 days

questions.text: A 40-year-old man previously diagnosed with hepatitis B is found to have the following serologic profile at his follow-up: HBsAg: Negative Anti-HBs: Positive Anti-HBc (IgG): Positive HBeAg: Negative Anti-HBe: Positive Which of the following best describes this patient's condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Resolved past infection with protective immunity

questions.correct_answer: C. Resolved past infection with protective immunity
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Resolved past infection with protective immunity

questions.text: Which of the following statements about chemoprophylaxis in cholera is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Recommended for all individuals in affected districts

options.label: B
options.text: Azithromycin is the drug of choice for mass prophylaxis

options.label: C
options.text: Reserved for household contacts or closed communities only

options.label: D
options.text: Required in all pregnant women during outbreaks

questions.correct_answer: C. Reserved for household contacts or closed communities only
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Reserved for household contacts or closed communities only

questions.text: A stool survey in a tribal region shows an average of 240 hookworm eggs/gm of stool using the Kato-Katz technique. Based on Chandler’s index, which public health classification is most appropriate?
A 29-year-old woman diagnosed with cholera is found to be 10 weeks pregnant. Which of the following is true regarding vaccination against cholera and yellow fever in pregnancy?

options.label: A
options.text: Cholera and Yellow fever vaccines can be administered together

options.label: C
options.text: Live cholera vaccine is safe in early pregnancy

options.label: D
options.text: Cholera and Yellow fever vaccines should be spaced at least 3 weeks apart

questions.correct_answer: D. Cholera and Yellow fever vaccines should be spaced at least 3 weeks apart
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Cholera and Yellow fever vaccines should be spaced at least 3 weeks apart

questions.text: Based on the image, identify the disease characterized by transmission, seasonal variation and involvement of different type of hosts.

A public health officer is evaluating flea indices in a plague-endemic district. Which of the following combinations of rat and flea indicators would most strongly justify initiating mass chemoprophylaxis?

options.label: A
options.text: High total flea index, low burrow index, and decreasing Cheopsis index

options.label: B
options.text: Elevated Cheopsis index, high specific flea percentage, and presence of Xenopsylla cheopis

options.label: C
options.text: Low Cheopsis index, stable burrow index, and low Wayson-positive cases

options.label: D
options.text: Rising total flea index and decreased rodent capture rate

questions.correct_answer: B. Elevated Cheopsis index, high specific flea percentage, and presence of Xenopsylla cheopis
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Elevated Cheopsis index, high specific flea percentage, and presence of Xenopsylla cheopis

questions.text: During a refugee camp outbreak, several individuals develop high fever, delirium, and a louse infestation is noted. A few weeks later, a previously infected patient redevelops a milder febrile illness. This recurrence is most consistent with:

A 5-year-old child from an endemic district in India tests positive by the rk39 dipstick test and has hepatosplenomegaly. The health officer initiates treatment per NVDCP 2017–2018 guidelines. Which of the following is the correct first-line treatment under the national program?

You are involved in surveillance of non-venereal treponematoses in tropical regions. A seropositive population is being treated for endemic treponematoses with penicillin. Despite treatment, new ulcerative lesions continue to appear in multiple households. Which of the following public health errors most likely explains the failure in eradication?

options.label: A
options.text: Ignoring vertical transmission via congenital route

options.label: B
options.text: Confusion between syphilis and pinta due to cross-reactive tests

options.label: C
options.text: Inappropriate use of topical antifungals for early skin lesions

options.label: D
options.text: Relying solely on sexual transmission routes for contact tracing

questions.correct_answer: D. Relying solely on sexual transmission routes for contact tracing
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Relying solely on sexual transmission routes for contact tracing

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with vaginal discharge, and examination suggests candidal infection. Under India’s syndromic management approach, she is given a green kit containing fluconazole and secnidazole. Which of the following situations would most appropriately require this kit to be replaced with the yellow kit?

options.label: A
options.text: If the discharge is associated with vulvar itching

options.label: B
options.text: If the patient has genital ulcers in addition to discharge

options.label: C
options.text: If the discharge is associated with bilateral lower abdominal tenderness

options.label: D
options.text: If the patient reports recurrence within 7 days of treatment

questions.correct_answer: C. If the discharge is associated with bilateral lower abdominal tenderness
questions.explanation: Ans. C) If the discharge is associated with bilateral lower abdominal tenderness

questions.text: A 26-year-old man returns from a wildlife photography expedition in Gujarat. He presents with flu-like illness 6 days later. Labs reveal thrombocytopenia and elevated liver enzymes. The illness worsens to hemorrhagic manifestations. Which of the following features best differentiates Crimean Congo Fever from Brucellosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Direct contact with aborted placenta and urine

options.label: C
options.text: Tick-borne transmission with short incubation and high mortality

questions.correct_answer: C. Tick-borne transmission with short incubation and high mortality
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Tick-borne transmission with short incubation and high mortality

questions.text: A policymaker aims to design a hypertension control program for a semi-urban population. She wants to implement primary prevention at the population level. Which of the following is the most appropriate goal to align with this strategy?

options.label: A
options.text: Treat all individuals with SBP >140 mmHg

options.label: B
options.text: Screen only symptomatic hypertensives in the population

options.label: C
options.text: Shift the entire BP distribution of the population to the left

options.label: D
options.text: Identify and treat only diagnosed hypertensive individuals

questions.correct_answer: C. Shift the entire BP distribution of the population to the left
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Shift the entire BP distribution of the population to the left

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Glycaemic Index (GI) is/are correct? GI measures the area under the 2-hour glucose response curve. Sweet potatoes are classified as low GI foods. Brown rice and basmati rice fall in the medium GI category. Lentils are low GI foods and have slower glucose absorption.
Assertion (A): Waist-hip ratio (WHR) is considered a better predictor of cardiovascular risk than BMI. Reason (R): WHR is age- and sex-dependent and less reliable than skinfold thickness.

options.label: A
options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A

options.label: B
options.text: Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A

options.label: C
options.text: A is true, but R is false

options.label: D
options.text: A is false, but R is true

questions.correct_answer: C. A is true, but R is false
questions.explanation: Ans. C) A is true, but R is false

questions.text: A public health team is conducting chronic disease risk factor surveillance in a tribal district using the WHO STEPS framework. Which of the following statements regarding the approach are accurate? Behavioral risk factors are collected only in STEP 2 under expanded assessment. STEP 3 is essential for estimating population lipid profiles and should include HDL. Waist circumference and BP are included in STEP 2 measurements. History of diabetes and hypertension is only included if biochemical measurements are taken.

A 27-year-old animal control officer is attending a municipal planning meeting to design strategies for reducing rabies cases in a densely populated urban area. The city has reported a rise in dog bites but limited human rabies cases. The health department must adopt a logical, cost-effective, and population-level approach for rabies control. Which of the following strategies is most appropriate?

options.label: A
options.text: Test all stray and pet dogs in the city for rabies infection

options.label: B
options.text: Remove all stray dogs and vaccinate the remaining dog population

options.label: C
options.text: Administer rabies vaccine to the entire human population

options.label: D
options.text: Focus on health education of the urban population

questions.correct_answer: B. Remove all stray dogs and vaccinate the remaining dog population
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Remove all stray dogs and vaccinate the remaining dog population

questions.text: Which of the following are true about the Nikshay Mitra Initiative (NMI) under Pradhan Mantri TB Mukt Bharat Abhiyaan? It was launched by the President of India in 2022. It aims to reduce stigma by allowing adoption of TB patients. Only dietary and nutritional support can be offered under the scheme. Corporate bodies can participate under CSR for providing support.
A tertiary hospital uses opt-out testing for HIV under NACP. Which of the following is a false assumption about the policy’s implementation?

options.label: A
options.text: Patients are informed that testing is routine, but may refuse

options.label: B
options.text: Consent is not necessary since testing is standard practice

options.label: C
options.text: Testing rate is expected to be above 85%

options.label: D
options.text: WHO and CDC support this testing model in healthcare settings

questions.correct_answer: B. Consent is not necessary since testing is standard practice
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Consent is not necessary since testing is standard practice

questions.text: A field entomologist captures female Phlebotomus argentipes in a Kala Azar–endemic region. Which of the following statements is false regarding its role in disease transmission?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a poor flyer and typically rests in dark, humid places like cracks and crevices

options.label: B
options.text: It is the vector for cutaneous leishmaniasis in India

options.label: C
options.text: Only the female sandfly is hematophagous

options.label: D
options.text: It transmits the parasite by injecting promastigotes during a blood meal

questions.correct_answer: B. It is the vector for cutaneous leishmaniasis in India
questions.explanation: Ans. B) It is the vector for cutaneous leishmaniasis in India

questions.text: Identify which of the following statements are True or False regarding ASHA indicators:

A 19-year-old pregnant woman from a Below Poverty Line (BPL) family delivers at a government district hospital. She receives ₹1,400 under Janani Suraksha Yojana but is asked to pay for the blood transfusion and diagnostics. Which of the following most accurately explains the policy breach?

options.label: A
options.text: JSY does not cover diagnostics or transfusion

options.label: B
options.text: She is ineligible for JSSK as it applies only to caesarean deliveries

options.label: C
options.text: JSSK covers diagnostics and transfusion free of cost, which were wrongly charged

options.label: D
options.text: JSY includes both cash assistance and in-kind services at all levels

questions.correct_answer: C. JSSK covers diagnostics and transfusion free of cost, which were wrongly charged
questions.explanation: Ans. C) JSSK covers diagnostics and transfusion free of cost, which were wrongly charged

questions.text: A municipal planner is tasked with establishing U-PHCs across towns with varying population sizes. One of the towns has a population of 48,000. According to policy, under which national mission should this town fall for primary healthcare coverage?

options.label: A
options.text: Covered under NUHM since it's below 50,000

options.label: B
options.text: Excluded from both NUHM and NRHM

options.label: C
options.text: Covered under NRHM since towns below 50,000 fall under rural health planning

options.label: D
options.text: Covered only if classified as a backward area under NITI Aayog guidelines

questions.correct_answer: C. Covered under NRHM since towns below 50,000 fall under rural health planning
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Covered under NRHM since towns below 50,000 fall under rural health planning

questions.text: A postgraduate community medicine student is analyzing recent structural reforms in national child and maternal health schemes. According to the latest reorganization under the Ministry of Women and Child Development, which of the following umbrella initiatives covers Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) and the Scheme for Adolescent Girls?

Which of the following statements regarding daily iodine intake are true ? Pregnant women require more iodine than school-aged children. Preschool children need 150 mcg iodine daily to prevent cretinism. 250 mcg/day of iodine is recommended for lactating mothers. Adults (>12 years) should consume 90 mcg/day of iodine.

options.label: D
options.text: None of the combinations is true

questions.correct_answer: D. None of the combinations is true
questions.explanation: Ans. D) None of the combinations is true

questions.text: Which of the following statements are correct regarding reproductive health indicators? TFR includes births to a woman throughout her reproductive years using ASFRs. GFR considers all live births in a year divided by total mid-year population. GRR counts the number of daughters a woman would bear in her lifetime. NRR equals 1 when the population is just replacing itself.
You are posted in a tribal region where the Annual Growth Rate (AGR) is estimated at 0.3%. Applying demographic classifications, which of the following best describes the population dynamics?

options.label: D
options.text: Very rapid growth; doubling in 35–47 years

questions.correct_answer: B. Slow growth; doubling in >139 years
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Slow growth; doubling in >139 years

questions.text: Which statement best reflects the dependency ratio challenge and its economic consequence in Country A compared to Country B?

options.label: A
options.text: Country A’s high youth dependency will strain education and child health budgets

options.label: B
options.text: Country B’s youth bulge will decrease per capita income due to unemployment

options.label: C
options.text: Country A’s increasing old-age dependency will lead to pension burden and reduced workforce

options.label: D
options.text: Country B will face healthcare cost surges due to aging-related degenerative diseases

questions.correct_answer: C. Country A’s increasing old-age dependency will lead to pension burden and reduced workforce
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Country A’s increasing old-age dependency will lead to pension burden and reduced workforce

questions.text: A study reports 18 pregnancies over 2,700 woman-months of oral contraceptive use. What is the approximate Pearl Index?
Which of the following statements regarding the use of contraceptive (as shown in the image) is true?

options.label: A
options.text: It should be left in situ for ≥24 hours for optimal efficacy.

options.label: B
options.text: It must be removed immediately after intercourse to prevent PID.

options.label: C
options.text: It offers protection against both pregnancy and STIs including HIV.

options.label: D
options.text: It should be left in situ for 6–8 hours after intercourse.

questions.correct_answer: D. It should be left in situ for 6–8 hours after intercourse.
questions.explanation: Ans. D) It should be left in situ for 6–8 hours after intercourse.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman who smokes 10 cigarettes/day presents for contraception counseling. Her BMI is 29, and she is normotensive. She asks about starting combined oral pills. Which statement best reflects the relative risk in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Smoking alone is a contraindication to combined OCPs, regardless of age.

options.label: B
options.text: Age >40 years combined with smoking increases cardiovascular risk, requiring caution.

options.label: C
options.text: She can be prescribed COCPs without restrictions.

options.label: D
options.text: OCPs are safe in smokers unless they have hypertension or diabetes.

questions.correct_answer: B. Age >40 years combined with smoking increases cardiovascular risk, requiring caution.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Age >40 years combined with smoking increases cardiovascular risk, requiring caution.

questions.text: Which of the following cases is correctly matched with the required number of medical practitioners under the MTP Act?

options.label: B
options.text: 23 weeks pregnant woman with fetal anencephaly – 1 doctor

options.label: C
options.text: 16 weeks gestation due to consensual sex – 1 doctor

options.label: D
options.text: 26 weeks with Down syndrome diagnosis – 2 doctors

questions.correct_answer: C. 16 weeks gestation due to consensual sex – 1 doctor
questions.explanation: Ans. C) 16 weeks gestation due to consensual sex – 1 doctor

questions.text: Rank the following diseases in descending order based on their maximum incubation period (longest to shortest): Tuberculosis HIV/AIDS Hepatitis B Leptospirosis Choose the correct ranking:

Which of the following statements regarding the National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) daily treatment guidelines and incentives is/are true? Patients are given daily fixed-dose combinations to reduce pill burden and improve compliance. Incentives for DOTS providers are higher for MDR/XDR-TB patients than for Category I patients. Extension of the intensive phase is routinely recommended in case of slow responders. Paediatric patients receive bitter but highly effective tablets under the national program.
Which of the following is true regarding the treatment of P. vivax + P. falciparum infection in a 30-year-old in Madhya Pradesh?

options.label: A
options.text: Treat with ACT-AL and Primaquine for 2 weeks

options.label: B
options.text: Treat as P. vivax with Chloroquine only

options.label: C
options.text: Treat as P. falciparum with ACT-SP and Primaquine

options.label: D
options.text: Only P. vivax regimen is recommended in mixed cases

questions.correct_answer: C. Treat as P. falciparum with ACT-SP and Primaquine
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Treat as P. falciparum with ACT-SP and Primaquine

questions.text: You are comparing two patients in a government clinic: a 4-year-old boy and a 25-year-old pregnant woman in her second trimester. According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat protocol, what is the correct iron–folic acid dosing and frequency for each?

options.label: A
options.text: 4-year-old: 20 mg iron + 100 mcg FA daily; Pregnant woman: 60 mg iron + 500 mcg FA biweekly

options.label: B
options.text: 4-year-old: 20 mg iron + 100 mcg FA biweekly; Pregnant woman: 60 mg iron + 500 mcg FA daily

options.label: C
options.text: 4-year-old: 45 mg iron + 400 mcg FA weekly; Pregnant woman: 45 mg iron + 400 mcg FA weekly

options.label: D
options.text: 4-year-old: 40 mg iron + 100 mcg FA weekly; Pregnant woman: 60 mg iron + 400 mcg FA daily

questions.correct_answer: B. 4-year-old: 20 mg iron + 100 mcg FA biweekly; Pregnant woman: 60 mg iron + 500 mcg FA daily
questions.explanation: Ans. B) 4-year-old: 20 mg iron + 100 mcg FA biweekly; Pregnant woman: 60 mg iron + 500 mcg FA daily
